thread.title: NASA astronaut throws 'longest Hail Mary' pass ahead of Super Bowl
thread.title_full: NASA astronaut throws 'longest Hail Mary' pass ahead of Super Bowl

title: NASA astronaut throws 'longest Hail Mary' pass ahead of Super Bowl
text:
Map: United States 
NASA has released video showing an astronaut on the International Space Station throwing a football in honour of Sunday's Super Bowl in the United States. 
The space crew attempted to see just how far they could throw a football in a zero gravity environment. 
The space station orbits earth at 28,000 kilometres per hour, the agency said, which meant the ball travelled about 8,000 metres per second. 
All up, it covered 500,000 metres according to NASA, which called it the "longest Hail Mary pass" ever. 
But it was unlikely the pass would be granted an actual world record, considering the astronaut who threw the ball was also technically travelling at high speed. 
The New England Patriots and the Atlanta Falcons will compete in the Super Bowl on February 5 (local time).
